narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General knowledge of evolution and the way science has been historically weaponized to devalue Africans. Understanding of the Cradle Paradox (professor's working theory) as a way of analyzing Africa as a continent and Africans as a diverse group. Developed critical reading skills through in-depth study of complicated research papers. Enhanced group work and presentation skills.
I learned a lot about topics that I had never explored before including de/coloniality, African history, social Darwinism, how science was misused for racist purposes, and more.
Analyzing Anthropology and Archeological sites; dimension of evolution in relation to different scientific and pseudo-scientific movements; reconcile with the cradle paradox and the implications.

I learned a lot about anthropology, which I have never explored in depth before. I learned about the cradle paradox and how a lot of western relies on the assumption of Africa as the cradle of humanity and that assumption is ingrained in our culture for example in the way museums are set up. I learned a lot about how locals react to scientists at their excavation sites.

I learned a lot about archeological, scientific, and cultural interpretations and ramifications of evolutionary theory across the African continent and how they feed into (and provide potential avenues for going against) colonial hierarchies.
A deeper understanding of the cradle paradox and contemporary criticisms of anthropology in africa

Before this class, I had no real understanding of anthropology. This class was a wonderful introduction to anthropology while emphasizing the importance of the field. I learned the intentionality behind studying cultures and the implications on Africa specifically. Im now more interested in African anthropology more than ever, and I find myself asking anthropological questions more than ever.
Critical analysis of colonialism and its lingering effect on society.
Understanding of how the pioneering studies in evolution have social repercussions until today. Looked at a variety of case studies as to how African society today is affected.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor checked in frequently with students regarding workload and status of understanding, many topics covered but with a cohesive theme and course thesis, only one traditional exam
Weakness: Not much feedback given on written assignments

This course was very interesting and covered a variety of topics. However, it seemed a little thrown together as we went, with readings and assignments changing from the syllabus. With readings assigned only a couple of days before class, it was hard to get ahead or feel prepared without being rushed. She also told us of our assignments, including the midterm and papers, about a week in advance, so I never felt like I knew what was going on in the course.

Course was fantastic in its design; Enjoy not only the topic and the work but the instruction ; The only improvement would be location of class; with the topics we are discussing, the class would fare better with better natural lighting
It was very eye opening and thorough. There was clearly a common theme of the cradle paradox and the Professor really drove that idea home.

The course covers a lot of topics, and as someone who had very little knowledge about these subjects ahead of time, it was nice to get a broader understanding rather than going into the weeds on very few topics. However, I think it could have been a bit better organized so that I could more easily make the connections across the different topics we covered.
Could be more clear about the goal of the course

Strengths: The readings were very interesting, the flexibility in essays and presentations allowed students to explore whatever they desired, this class also attracted a very diverse set of students, breaks
Weaknesses: The discussions were hard to initiate with certain topics
a little disorganized

Sometimes switching from lecture into group dicussions made it difficult to generate dicussion since we were focused on notes and listening rather than conversation among students. We did start to switch this order later in the semester which helpled. Also taking into account class seating would help with discussion since often times distance made it dicussion more impersonal. Due to the size of the class smaller discussions may have helped. Besides that I loved the material and the openess offered to us during class. Especially how Prof. Waweru would weave our own considerations and opinions into class regularly.
The topics are unique and things I have never had the ability to study academically before. All the topics are connected under the classes name.
This course was excellent for studying social phenomena in Africa- from skin bleaching to Afro-futurism. Helps contextualize how some of these practices emerge.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who wants to dabble in African Studies and/or Anthropology. This course blended those two disciplines seamlessly, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Anyone who wants to take a collaborative course involving both the scientific method/fact-based learning and humanities/writing and reading skills would enjoy this class.

I had a fantastic time taking this course. Dr Waweru did a great job of introducing us to the cradle paradox and taking us through related concepts, while also allowing a strong amount of class discussion. Definitely recommend!
Definitely

Yes. It is a very interesting course and everyone gets a chance to present on something. When someone presents, everyone listens and asks questions. Its a good environment, very positive and low pressure, so I had a great time learning.
Yes
Yes! Im so happy I took this class because its a VERY interesting subject that makes things less like work and more like genuine learning.
it was kind of disorganized so if you're ok with that - then sure
Yes 100%, possibly one of my favorite classes at Yale. Incredibily informative, a dynamic setting that always made me excited to learn.
Yes. Fascinating and good opportunity to write interesting papers.
Yes
Yes. This class had excellent course material which allowed for really vibrant and enjoyable discussion. The workload was not high, and each assignment was enjoyable.
